G.L. c. 218, \u00a719.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §19 and G.L. c. 185C, §3, as the amount in controversy is less than $50,000 and arises from a residential tenancy located in Chelsea, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 185C, \u00a73.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §19 and G.L. c. 185C, §3, as the amount in controversy is less than $50,000 and arises from a residential tenancy located in Chelsea, Massachusetts.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a71.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court because the rental premises are located in Chelsea and the events giving rise to this action occurred therein.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a714.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, §14, a landlord may not “directly or indirectly interfere with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant.” A violation entitles the tenant to actual and statutory damages.

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in every tenancy.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses the nature of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and explicitly states that every tenancy is deemed to include an implied covenant by the landlord not to disturb the tenant’s quiet enjoyment. That is exactly the proposition for which the case is being cited, and the statement is part of the court’s doctrinal explanation of G.L. c. 186, § 14 and the common law background, not mere dicta.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ … Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy.”  Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (1982).

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716\.proposition: A landlord breaches this covenant when their conduct, or failure to act, substantially interferes with the tenant’s beneficial use and enjoyment of the premises.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716\.support_reasoning: The court explicitly states that a landlord can breach the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment even without intent, where the breach is the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, failed to do, or permitted, and where the result is substantial deprivation of the tenant’s use and enjoyment. The opinion holds the landlords liable because their conduct in leasing and permitting operation of the noisy lounge, and failing effectively to abate it though they had control, substantially interfered with the tenants’ beneficial enjoyment. This squarely matches the proposition that a landlord’s conduct or failure to act that substantially interferes with a tenant’s beneficial use constitutes breach.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 716\.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done… Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable.”

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.proposition: Defendant’s failure to repair a defective entry door lock after notice constitutes a substantial interference with Plaintiff’s right to safely and privately occupy her dwelling.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.support_reasoning: The opinion directly states that a landlord’s failure to repair defects in leased premises after notice is conduct that frequently violates G.L. c. 186, § 14, the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment. Although the case concerns lead paint, the court’s reasoning and citations make clear that negligent non-repair after notice, including of defects like doors or locks, can constitute a substantial interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment, which encompasses safe and private occupancy of the dwelling.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.relevant_excerpt: We noted that a landlord’s failure “to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.” See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959, 960 (1985) (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so).

Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.raw_text: Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196, 199 (1979)
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.proposition: The repeated unauthorized entries and Theft of tenant mail are consequences directly flowing from Defendant’s neglect, which courts have found constitute breaches of quiet enjoyment.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.support_reasoning: The case deals with loss of heat and hot water as a breach of the implied warranty of habitability and the resulting right to rent abatement. It does not involve, discuss, or analyze repeated unauthorized entries, theft of tenant mail, or breach of quiet enjoyment as such. Therefore it cannot be cited as authority that such entries or mail theft are consequences of the landlord’s neglect constituting a breach of quiet enjoyment.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “He found and ruled that the losses of heat and hot water were material breaches of the warranty of habitability… We must decide (1) whether a tenant must pay full rent without abatement when the landlord, acting without fault or bad faith, fails to maintain a dwelling in habitable condition… We hold that the tenant’s obligation abates as soon as the landlord has notice that premises fail to comply with the requirements of the warranty of habitability.”

Fafard v. Lincoln Pharmacy of Milford, I.raw_text: Fafard v. Lincoln Pharmacy of Milford, Inc., 439 Mass. 512, 517 (2003).
Fafard v. Lincoln Pharmacy of Milford, I.proposition: Defendant’s conduct in ignoring Plaintiff’s repeated complaints demonstrates reckless disregard for her right to quiet enjoyment, similar to the landlord’s neglect found actionable in Fafard v. Lincoln Pharmacy of Milford, Inc., 439 Mass. 512, 517 (2003).
Fafard v. Lincoln Pharmacy of Milford, I.case_name: Fafard v. Lincoln Pharmacy of Milford, Inc.
Fafard v. Lincoln Pharmacy of Milford, I.support_reasoning: The opinion is about whether counterclaims are procedurally allowed in commercial summary process actions; it does not address quiet enjoyment, landlord neglect, or reckless disregard of a tenant’s rights. There is no discussion of conditions of the premises, complaints by a tenant about interference, or any tort- or covenant-based quiet enjoyment analysis. Using this case to show that ignoring complaints can constitute reckless disregard for quiet enjoyment misstates its holding and subject matter.
Fafard v. Lincoln Pharmacy of Milford, I.relevant_excerpt: “We transferred this case here on our own motion to decide whether a counterclaim may be filed in a commercial summary process action, particularly given the adoption of the rule of mutually dependant covenants in commercial leases… Because we agree with the trial judge’s determination that a counterclaim is not a proper procedural device in a commercial summary process action, we affirm the judgment entered in the Superior Court.”

G.L. c. 93A, \u00a72.proposition: Defendant’s failure to maintain security also violates G.L. c. 186, §14 and G.L. c. 93A, §2, as construed in Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982) (security-related defects deemed interference).

Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.raw_text: Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982)
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.proposition: Defendant’s failure to maintain security also violates G.L. c. 186, §14 and G.L. c. 93A, §2, as construed in Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 982 (1982) (security-related defects deemed interference).
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.support_reasoning: Lowery v. Robinson concerns a landlord’s failure to furnish heat and holds that such failure constitutes interference with quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, §14, supporting civil damages, but it does not address building security, security-related defects, or G.L. c. 93A, §2. The proposition extends Lowery’s holding to security conditions and to a Chapter 93A violation, which this opinion neither discusses nor decides. Thus, citing Lowery for the notion that security-related defects are deemed interference, or that such failures violate c. 93A, misstates its scope.
Lowery v. Robinson, 13 Mass. App. Ct. 98.relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season…seriously ‘impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises’…and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment… It is not necessary to recovery that the landlord intended to violate the covenant. Rather ‘the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.’… On the facts found by the judge, the tenant was entitled on the quiet enjoyment claim to…a declaration that the landlords had violated G. L. c. 186, § 14… and an assessment of damages and counsel fees under § 14.”

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: Massachusetts courts have imposed liability under §14 for persistent violations affecting safety or habitability.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The case directly construes G.L. c. 186, § 14 (the quiet enjoyment statute) and holds that a landlord may be liable where its failure to act in the face of serious, ongoing criminal activity on the premises causes a substantial interference with tenants’ use and enjoyment. The court reverses summary judgment on the § 14 claim and remands for fact-finding on whether the housing authority’s inaction amid pervasive drug-related crime and threats—which clearly implicate safety and habitability—constituted a breach. That squarely supports the proposition that Massachusetts courts have imposed (or will impose) liability under § 14 for persistent violations affecting safety or habitability.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt:
“If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.

We conclude that the judge erred in granting summary judgment for the defendant on the plaintiffs’ claim of violation of G. L. c. 186, § 14. There must be a trial to determine what, if any, measures the defendant has taken … and to determine the seriousness or substantiality of the interference with the tenancies.”

Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.raw_text: Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 744 (2005)
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.proposition: Massachusetts courts have imposed liability under §14 for persistent violations affecting safety or habitability.
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses G. L. c. 186, § 14 and the covenant of quiet enjoyment, but only to conclude that there was no breach and thus no liability. It does not involve, describe, or affirm any instance where liability under § 14 was imposed for persistent violations affecting safety or habitability; instead, it finds prompt repairs and no serious interference with the tenancy. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority that Massachusetts courts have imposed liability under § 14 in such circumstances.
Jablonski v. Casey, 64 Mass. App. Ct. 74.relevant_excerpt: “Casey counterclaimed that York breached her covenant of quiet enjoyment. Similar to the warranty of habitability, during the rental of any residential premises, there exists an implied covenant and a statutory right of quiet enjoyment. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102 (1982); G. L. c. 186, § 14. … Here, York acted immediately upon being notified by Casey of the defective conditions… The trial judge did not err in denying the requested ruling of law that a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment had occurred. We see no evidence in the record before us of interference with Casey’s quiet enjoyment of the premises.”

Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.raw_text: Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 907 (1987)
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.proposition: Massachusetts courts have imposed liability under §14 for persistent violations affecting safety or habitability.
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.support_reasoning: The opinion never cites or discusses G.L. c. 186, § 14, nor does it analyze liability for interference with quiet enjoyment or for persistent conditions affecting safety or habitability under that statute. The case addresses security deposits, rent control overcharges, warranty of habitability, utilities obligations under the sanitary code, and c. 93A, but any discussion of code violations appears only in the context of a common‑law warranty/breach analysis, not § 14. Therefore it cannot be relied on as authority that Massachusetts courts have imposed liability under § 14 for persistent safety or habitability violations.
Young v. Patukonis, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 90.relevant_excerpt:
Several violations of the State Sanitary Code, 105 Code Mass. Regs. § 410.000 (1983), have existed in the tenant’s apartment since Young and his mother acquired the property. The judge concluded, however, that most of the conditions had minimal impact on the use and enjoyment of the apartment and that Young had been fairly responsive to the tenant’s requests for repairs.

…

Patukonis challenges the judge’s award of $625 in damages for the breach of warranty of habitability…

Lipsitt v. Plaisted, 466 Mass. 240, 245\.proposition: Defendant’s failure to provide adequate building security also constitutes a violation of the landlord’s duty to maintain common areas in a reasonably safe condition, reinforcing the breach of the covenant.
Lipsitt v. Plaisted, 466 Mass. 240, 245\.support_reasoning: The opinion in Lipsitt v. Plaisted concerns whether the Massachusetts Wage Act preempts common-law contract and quasi-contract claims for unpaid wages and issues of piercing the corporate veil. It does not address landlord-tenant law, building security, or a landlord’s duty to maintain common areas in a reasonably safe condition. Therefore, it cannot serve as authority for the proposition about inadequate building security and breach of the covenant regarding common areas.
Lipsitt v. Plaisted, 466 Mass. 240, 245\.relevant_excerpt: “In this case, we are asked to decide whether G. L. c. 149, §§ 148 and 150 (Wage Act), are intended to be the exclusive remedy for the recovery of unpaid wages under Massachusetts law, preempting common-law breach of contract and related quasi-contract claims. We conclude that they are not.”
